counties.name: Bexar
counties.demographicsBlurb: Bexar County (pop. ~2.09M) is majority Hispanic (59.8%) with substantial bilingual households (37.7% speak a language other than English at home). Median age is 35.0; bachelor's+ attainment is 32.8%; median household income is about $69.8k with 14.7% below poverty, supporting large, mixed urban/suburban jury pools and damages narratives that can vary materially by venue within the county.
counties.politicalBlurb: Countywide elections have leaned Democratic in recent cycles (driven by San Antonio urban core), while outer suburban precincts remain more competitive and can tighten judicial/down-ballot margins. For trial strategy, assume partisan heterogeneity by precinct and ballot position rather than a uniform countywide profile.

counties.name: Travis
counties.demographicsBlurb: Travis County (pop. ~1.33M) has a high-education, high-income profile (58.7% bachelor's+; median household income about $97.5k) with lower poverty (10.2%) and median age 36.1. Hispanic residents are 32.4%, and 30.4% of households speak a language other than English at home. Austin's tech/government economy and education concentration can shape jury expectations around documentation, expert testimony, and institutional conduct.
counties.politicalBlurb: Travis is one of Texas' strongest Democratic counties in countywide federal elections; however, neighborhood-level ideology and class differences (urban core vs. growth corridors) still matter in voir dire and damages framing. Judicial and local-issue contests may show narrower spreads than headline partisan results.

counties.name: Harris
counties.demographicsBlurb: Harris County (pop. ~4.84M) is the state's largest jury pool and highly diverse (44.1% Hispanic; 45.3% language other than English at home). Median age is 34.8; bachelor's+ attainment is 34.2%; median household income is about $72.3k with 16.0% below poverty. The county's scale and socioeconomic dispersion can produce substantial variation in juror attitudes between urban core, industrial corridors, and outer suburbs.
counties.politicalBlurb: Recent countywide outcomes generally favor Democrats, but Harris remains a true battleground at the precinct level: suburban and exurban sectors can swing, and some judicial races are materially closer than top-of-ticket results. Expect meaningful intra-county political variance in panel composition.

courts.name: 55th District Court
courts.judgeProfileBlurb: Official Harris/Justex court roster lists Judge Latosha Lewis Payne for the 55th District Court.
courts.judgePoliticalBlurb: If included, derive only from verifiable public election disclosures.
courts.publicInfo: Official Justex API roster (`/JustexAPI/api/Courts/?CourtClassID=1`) resolves 55th District Court judge as Latosha Lewis Payne, floor 9, phone (832) 927-2650. Coordinator/bailiff fields remain pending because this endpoint does not expose staff contacts; keep staff verification queued for court-specific official pages. Dropbox/eFiling note: verify current county clerk or district clerk filing instructions.

counties.name: Hidalgo
counties.demographicsBlurb: Hidalgo County (pop. ~898k) is heavily Hispanic (91.9%) with very high bilingual relevance (78.4% language other than English at home) and a younger profile (median age 30.9). Bachelor's+ attainment is 20.7%; median household income is about $53.7k; poverty is 27.2%. These indicators are litigation-relevant for communication style, economic-loss framing, and practical access-to-care/workforce evidence.
counties.politicalBlurb: Hidalgo has historically leaned Democratic, but recent cycles show notable rightward movement in parts of the Rio Grande Valley. Practically, counsel should not treat the county as a static partisan environment; precinct-level shifts and turnout volatility can materially affect jury composition and narrative resonance.

counties.name: Dallas
counties.demographicsBlurb: Dallas County (pop. ~2.61M) combines dense urban venues with fast-changing suburbs; 41.4% of residents are Hispanic and 43.2% speak a language other than English at home. Median age is 34.3; bachelor's+ attainment is 36.5%; median household income is about $74.4k with 13.7% below poverty. Commercial-employer concentration and demographic dispersion can influence both liability framing and damages expectations by courtroom and panel source area.
counties.politicalBlurb: Countywide voting trends Democratic, but the county is not monolithic: urban Dallas precincts differ from northern/eastern suburban precincts, and judicial contests can run meaningfully tighter than presidential baselines. Venue-specific jury strategy should account for precinct-level polarization and turnout differences.
